page_analysis.text_content:
Roofed porches on the 1st floor

How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

Fig 5  Roofed 1st floor porch

Step 1:  Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into segments that will allow a comparison of closed and open segments.

The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is shown below. It is the sum of segments A through G. It is 70 linear feet.

8

visual_elements.description: 3D isometric drawing of a two-story house with a roofed porch on the first floor. The house shows detailed architectural features including windows, doors, railings, and structural elements.
visual_elements.location: Left side of page, middle section

visual_elements.description: Floor plan/perimeter diagram showing the porch layout with labeled segments A through G. Includes dimensional annotations with letters D, E, F marking different measurements. Shows measurements including 8' for segment B and 24' for segment F.
visual_elements.location: Right side of page, middle to bottom section

subheadings: How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

additional_notes: Page number 8 appears at bottom left
Gray header bar appears under main heading
Dimensional labels A through G are used to identify perimeter segments
cross_references: Reference to 'Fig 5 as an example' in subheading
Reference to segments 'A through G' in perimeter calculation
